value: — the center of the region and one of the oldest cities in Belarus. Hrodna is a home to a 12th-century church, an old castle, and numerous remarkable buildings from the late 17th-early 20th century.
— a town with several interesting churches and a well-preserved brick synagogue.

— a small town with a nice Catholic church from 17th century and a number of interesting secular buildings.
— a settlement with an old Catholic church and an unusual wooden mosque, one of the few surviving pieces of the traditional architecture of the Belarusian Tatars.
— an ancient town with the ruins of a 13th-century castle and fine churches from the 18th-19th century.

(Holszany) – a village with a ruined castle and a Baroque monastery, once a seat of a princely Holszanski family.

– a town with a 14th-century castle where Kęstutis of Lithuania was murdered and the first union treaty between Poland and Lithuania was signed.

— one of the most-known destinations in Belarus, with an original castle from the 16th century and a nice old town with 19th-century buildings.

Usyalub — a village with a Catholic church from the 15th century. In the 19th century, the village was owned by a branch of the Irish O'Rourke family, whose funeral chapel survives to the present day.
Zhyrovichy — a village that is home to a large monastery dating back to the early 17th century.

churches can be seen in several regions of Europe (notably in Transylvania in Romania). Those in Belarus add one more element to the curious blend: they are Orthodox, and the corresponding architectural tradition has its share of influence on these buildings as well.
